Recap on list slicing

Here are the key concepts from the list slicing section. Please make sure you know them before proceeding.

Concept Example
You can get a subsequence of elements from a list by following the list name with two colon-separated indices in square brackets. This is called "slicing". 
names = ["Tau", "Maria", "Ng"]
names[1:3] # A slice of the names list
A slice of a list is itself a list, starting from the first subscript up to but not including the second subscript. 
names[1:3] # is the list ["Maria", "Ng"]
As before, negative subscripts count backwards from the end. 
names[0:-1] # is the list["Tau", "Maria"]
If you omit the first subscript, it defaults to 0 
names[:2]
If you omit the second subscript, it defaults to len(list) 
names[1:] # is the list ["Maria", "Ng"]
You can use a third subscript as a step size or "stride". 
names[0:3:2] # is the list ["Tau", "Ng"]
Slicing can be used to avoid "aliasing". 
copy = names[:]
copy[0] = "Angus" # names is unchanged
